pageContext.title: Jack Ma co-founded Alibaba with 17 other people. Here are their stories
pageContext.content:
Photo credit: Alibaba

This article is part of Tech in Asia’s partnership with iPrice Group where we publish the firm’s valuable insights on various ecommerce markets in Asia. For more articles in this series, go here.

Jack Ma has announced his retirement from Alibaba Group at 54. He led the 19-year-old company from humble beginnings in his apartment to an ecommerce giant that’s worth US$420 billion today.

While Ma has been the face of Alibaba, there were 17 other significant individuals who co-founded the company in 1999. But who are they?

We at iPrice Group embarked on a research to uncover the 18 founding members of Alibaba Group and summarized our findings in an infographic.

From this report, we found several interesting insights. For one, the co-founders were from diverse industries such as journalism, investment banking, web development, and education. Ma’s connections were established through his ex-students, ex-colleagues, mutual friends, and like-minded entrepreneurs.

Interestingly, there are three couples in the founding team. And among the 18 co-founders are six women, including Lazada CEO Lucy Peng, who now hold top-level management roles.

To discover more about Alibaba’s co-founders, here are more details on their backgrounds and how they met Ma:

Jack Ma

Ma was born on September 10, 1964 in Hangzhou, China at the time of communism. In 1988, he successfully earned his degree in English from Hangzhou Teacher’s Institute.

Later, Ma became an English and international trade lecturer at the Hangzhou Dianzi University. Eventually, he ventured into business and founded China Yellow Pages, the country’s first internet company. Ma also managed an information technology company for the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Co-operation or MOFTEC (presently Ministry of Commerce of the People’s Republic of China or MOFCOM).

In 1999, he initiated a meeting in his apartment together with his 17 co-founders to develop their first ecommerce venture, now known as Alibaba Group.

Today, Ma is the CEO and chairman of Alibaba, which has grown exponentially since its inception in 1999. The company has approximately 617 million monthly mobile users and 552 million active users on its China retail marketplaces, Tmall and Taobao.

At 54, Ma announced his retirement as chairman of Alibaba Group in September 2019 to concentrate on his philanthropy and education. Alibaba CEO Daniel Zhang will be his successor.

Jin Jianhang

Jin Jianhang was a top-performing student from Fudan Journalism School and worked at numerous Chinese media companies (Zhejiang Daily, International Business Daily).

Jin and Ma first met during the journalist’s interview with the entrepreneur during the China Yellow Pages days. As a business journalist, Jin would always encounter Ma, which eventually built a strong connection between them.

In 1999, Jin decided to join Ma and the other co-founders in building Alibaba.

Joseph Tsai

Joseph Tsai has degrees in economics, East Asian studies, and law. Prior to meeting Ma, he was an investment banker earning approximately US$700,000 annually.

Deeply inspired by Ma’s charisma and his idea for Alibaba, he made a daring move to give up his high-paying job to join Alibaba in 1999, earning only US$50 monthly.

Today, Tsai is the vice executive chairman and co-founder of Alibaba Group and ranks as its second largest individual shareholder after Ma.

Lucy Peng

Similar to Ma, Lucy Peng began her career as a teacher at the Zhejiang University of Finance and Economics. Peng quit teaching in 1999 to join her husband, Sun Tongyu, and be a part of the 18-strong Alibaba founding team. She is now the CEO of Lazada following Alibaba’s additional investment of US$2 billion into the marketplace.

Cathy Zhang

Cathy Zhang first met Ma at Hangzhou Teacher’s Institute. Soon after graduation, they got married. Zhang was in Alibaba’s management team and she now dedicates her time to raising their family.

Eddie Wu

Eddie Wu graduated with a computer science degree from the Zhejiang University of Technology in 1996. Then, he joined China Yellow Pages, where he first met Ma.

In 1997, Wu followed Ma to Beijing and assisted him by managing the MOFTEC website. Following Ma’s footsteps, Wu helped to build Alibaba Group as the company’s first programmer.

James Sheng

James Sheng began learning traditional art at an early age. He then turned to commercial art and started his career as a designer. He was acquainted with Ma when his company was hired to design China Yellow Pages’ website.

Sheng joined Ma’s meeting in his apartment and became one of the 18 founding members of Alibaba in 1999. Today, he is known to be the man behind Alibaba’s smile logo and is the co-founder and senior vice president of Alibaba Group.

Lou Wensheng

Lou Wensheng and Ma attended the same university, and Lou eventually became one of Ma’s closest supporters. In 1995, he decided to join China Yellow Pages after seeing the company on a TV documentary.

Simon Xie

Simon Xie obtained his degree in financial management from the Shenyang University of Technology, but his interest in computer led him to develop skills in information technology.

In 1996, he was attracted by Ma’s unique aura and decided to help him out in his ventures. Xie gave up his high-paying job in finance to work with Ma at MOFTEC, then Alibaba.

Jin Yuanying

Jin Yuanying was Ma’s student in Hangzhou Dianzi University. He was encouraged by Jane Jiang and Han Min to join Alibaba Group.

Zhou Yuehong

Zhou Yuehong is a Java architect and was Ma’s student at Hangzhou Dianzi University. Through his expertise in technology, Zhou developed the core code of MVC framework, WebX, which was mainly used for Taobao’s early days.

Shi Yufeng

In 1999, Shi Yufeng worked at Central Weather Bureau. Interestingly, he’s also good in technology, which came in handy when he joined Alibaba.

Wu noticed Shi’s presence in the internet world, so he introduced him to Ma. Attracted by Ma’s plan and passion for Alibaba, Shi decided to be a part of the company.

This article was first published on iPrice Insights.
